front.title: Network Monitoring and Managmenet standards in a Hostile World

section.title: Introduction
section.t: In order to understand the environmnent network managment and measurement work in the IETF is developed in it is important to have an understanding of the pressures on and preferences of the IETF community. It is also important to look at the historical milestones in the history of manangement and measurement protocol work and network instrumentation generally. Finally with that in mind we can inform the problems that future work will face along with places where points of contention are we believe evasive to consensus.

The authors, began this work by asking if monitoring and measrurement work previously chartered in the IETF (example IPFIX or previously Netflow) could be chartered today after RFC 7258 (Pervasive Monitoring Is an Attack). the answer is probably yes but the questions is insufficiently nuannced. Future work on the DNS, P2P networking, the HTTP protocol as well as IPv4/IPv6 and transport evolution may contribute to decreased surface area for pervasive monitoring, but if it also contributes to a decline in the managability of networks and services or exposes opertors to new forms of attack those are also considerations we should be mindful off.

section.title: Background
section.t: So long as IP netorks have existed, it has been necessary to carry information about topology (routing), manage the various network elements, facilitate diagnostics, and carry actual user traffic. For only a slightly shorter period of time, IP networks have been under attack, variously due to threats of availability, autheticity and access, integreity, and capture/reuse/replability

section.title: Pervasive Monitoring
section.t: The revelations present the Edward Snowden Whistle Blowing case were a capstone event in the long-standing efforts by state and non-state actors to peer into all aspects of internet communications as an extension of state control, law enforcement and miltary capabilites. the consequence of the developmnet of such capabilities is to subvert the integretigty of persional communitie

list.t: IETF standards already provide mechanisms to protect Internet communications and there are guidelines [RFC3552] for applying these in protocol design. But those standards generally do not address PM, the confidentiality of protocol metadata, countering traffic analysis, or data minimisation. In all cases, there will remain some privacy-relevant information that is inevitably disclosed by protocols. As technology advances, techniques that were once only available to extremely well-funded actors become more widely accessible. Mitigating PM is therefore a protection against a wide range of similar attacks. (RFC 7258 2)

section.t: While the recomendations in RFC 7258 for working on mitigation do not speficiatally target network monitoring and managment

section.title: Protocol interactions with PM and Security Considerations
IPFIX and flow monitoring generall and associated security considerations
section.t: Contratary to some popularized expectations, the migration of applications towards a general prefence towards port 80 and 443 and as has not rendered ipflow export less useful for ASPs or ISPs looking to monitor their traffic for usage patterns, performance, growth protection or abuse detection. Source and Destinations, connection establishment are all present. from the vantage-point of an application provider the applications tend to be well understood, so sampled ipfix even with limited metadata (such as ingress por and router) can reveal abuntdant information about how customers reach and use a service, when it is being attacked and so on.

Likewise while, at first glance a internet service providers' flow export might appear t o a be a poorly differentiated sample flows from their customers to their other costumers and peers, the concentration of applications under the ruberic of a few thousand realtively large and well understood application providers makes the nature of many such flows fairly straight forward to chracterize.

section.title: Example of Code or MIB Module To Be Extracted

figure.preamble: The <artwork> element has a number of extra attributes that can be used to substitute a more aesthetically pleasing rendition into HTML output while continuing to use the ASCII art version in the text and nroff outputs (see the xml2rfc README for details). It also has a "type" attribute. This is currently ignored except in the case 'type="abnf"'. In this case the "artwork" is expected to contain a piece of valid Augmented Backus-Naur Format (ABNF) grammar. This will be syntax checked by xml2rfc and any errors will cause a fatal error if the "strict" processing instruction is set to "yes". The ABNF will also be colorized in HTML output to highlight the syntactic components. Checking of additional "types" may be provided in future versions of xml2rfc.
